subject: RE: [EVP-ITC] Re: introducing myself
author: Frank Sumption

--_9b634b85-0269-4c6c-95ec-6c059afac2ff_

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Thanks. Spiricom did use 13 tone generators as away of produce something l=
ike that raw audio. Then transmitted the tones a short distance so they cou=
ld modulated by the spirits. What I think we've found is you don't have to =
transmit raw audio, the entities can manipuilate it in the electronics, it =
would seem. These days you can make four tone generators on a chip much sma=
ller then a dime. So you could have multiple tones in a small space, then w=
ith newer digital switching techniques, combine the tones in a way that wou=
ld similate speech bits. The goal as with all of this stuff is clear commun=
cation. I think it is way too soon, and not enough work has been done for a=
nyone to try to create theory of how this stuff work.   I used radio becasu=
e it's a convienient source of raw audio, but becasue of noise, and the var=
iations in the number of stations in different areas, it makes it an unreli=
able method. It works great here in Denver, it's not so good up in Cheyenne=
, Wyo, or Grand Junction, Co.    Frank-S


To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.comFrom:=
 overunder21@...: Mon, 3 Dec 2007 07:20:14 +0000Subject: [EVP-ITC=
] Re: introducing myself



I have read about tone generators myself but th=
at seems to be almost a step backward. Wasn't spiricom in essence a oscilli=
oscope/tone generator? I know it was considered for a while to be the most =
successful, but it was very electronic or synthetic in sound and required q=
uite an operational budget and space.I think with your invention we have re=
ached the cusp of being able to create the walkman of EVP/ITC - we're almos=
t there. And with the discovery of the Radioshack mod and the experience we=
 and others have had since your box first debuted I think we're almost to t=
he point where it will be very inexpensive to make a reliable box and/or so=
mething that the average person could make following instructions.Of course=
 the holy grail is something that reliably generates clear voices every tim=
e with little or no white noise. I know I read that someone was trying to c=
reate a device that did that, created the white noise and then cancelled it=
 out, hopefully leaving you with just the voice.Oh, and a reliable televisi=
on ITC device would be quite the find too. I plan on creating a RS mod box =
that will be self contained and portable...and my thought was if it works r=
eliably I wonder if I could integrate a simply video ITC generator into it =
as well. It would be great to be able to capture both audio and video.Anywa=
ys, carry on Frank. I know you're doing good work. IF you search the intern=
et for EVP and especially ghost box recordings your name is constantly popp=
ing up in the recordings, so I'm guessing those communicating with us are q=
uite happy with you.How does it feel to be the first known living person to=
 be a celebrity on the other side, lol?--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, Fran=
k Sumption <franks-boxes@...> wrote:>> > Yeah, I do seem to get answers to =
question with my Ghostman box (one of a kind Mini box). the Ghostman is a c=
ombinatin of the linear sweep and an AM/FM radio with direct out put, no so=
und chamber or mics. I have kinda palyed wiht white noise, but not for abou=
t six years. There's some ideas about using tone generators instead of radi=
o. > > Frank-S> > > > > To: EVP-ITC@...: overunder21@...: Sun, 2 Dec 2007 1=
3:50:23 +0000Subject: [EVP-ITC] introducing myself> > > > > Not really new =
to the group, been lurking for a few months just reading, listening, and st=
udying.Unfortunately I'm not much of an engineer so I've been picking up bo=
oks to help me better understand the technical side of the boxes. I underst=
and the practicality of them (ie- creating random white noise to allow EVPs=
 to be formed) but I hope to gain an understanding of how they work technic=
ally in hopes of building and tweaking my own.For me EVP has been something=
 I've been into all my life without knowing what it was (I'm 30 now, I firs=
t learned the technical term about 22 or 23) - I guess I'm what people woul=
d call 'sensitive' or whatever. But besides that, early on I was fascinated=
 by seemingly coherant sounds that would come out of random noise on my clo=
ck radio in my bedroom as a kid, from what sounded like voices (thought I w=
as crazy for a while) to even morse code - for a long time one of my radios=
 would produce random clicks or pops even when the speaker was off. My dad =
jokingly suggested it was morse code, so I studied morse code and discovere=
d that at least some of it could be morse letters...usually they would spel=
l one word and then gibberish.Anyways, once I learned what EVP was I began =
messing around with recorders etc. My first clear recording came from using=
 EVP maker and was someone saying 'we have been waiting for you.' A few day=
s later, after a frustrating lack of communication they just told me 'build=
 a box.(this happened to be after I learned of frank.)' I've been looking a=
t all the boxes and their positives and negatives and this is what I'm seei=
ng:Franks models seem to produce the most consistant results but also seem =
to be less two way than some others (ie Joe's Box.) Joe's Box and the new r=
adio shack mod seem to have some very clear voices coming through but skept=
ics can argue that all you are hearing is snippets from radio broadcasts.My=
 thought for a cost-effective, low-tech alternative is to combine the two i=
n that you create a radio shack mod like the UFOGeek one (multiple radios, =
a mixer, etc) and run it through an echo box.Personally I believe that anal=
og is giving the best results overall, and I think it has to do with ease o=
f manipulating the signal. Therefore my thought is taking a digital white n=
oise signal like that produced by the radio shack mods and then essentially=
 broadcasting it into the echo chamber and having a mic pick it up gives yo=
u the analog aspect.My question is has anyone tried this? And I was hoping =
for thoughts on the pros and cons of using AM vs. FM or both.Oh, one other =
thing- any programmers/engineers out there? Someone that could write code t=
o allow us to randomly band scan a digital radio? > > > > > > > ___________=
_______________________________________________> Share life as it happens w=
ith the new Windows Live.Download today it's FREE!> http://www.windowslive.=
com/share.html?ocid=3DTXT_TAGLM_Wave2_sharelife_112007> 






____________=
_____________________________________________________
You keep typing, we k=
eep giving. Download Messenger and join the i=92m Initiative now.

.live.com/messenger/im/home/?source=3DTAGLM
--_92b1a66c-2423-47d1-92a5-50e462af8154_

y of produce something like that raw audio. Then transmitted the tones a sh=
ort distance so they could modulated by the spirits. What I think we've fou=
nd is you don't have to transmit raw audio, the entities can manipuilate it=
 in the electronics, it would seem. These days you can make four tone gener=
ators on a chip much smaller then a dime. So you could have multi=
ple tones in a small space, then with newer digital switching techniques, c=
ombine the tones in a way that would similate speech bits. The goal as=
 with all of this stuff is clear communcation. I think it is way too soon, =
and not enough work has been done for anyone to try to create theory of how=
 this stuff work. <BR> <BR> I used radio becasue it's a convienie=
nt source of raw audio, but becasue of noise, and the variations in the num=
ber of stations in different areas, it makes it an unreliable method. It wo=
rks great here in Denver, it's not so good up in Cheyenne, Wyo, or Grand Ju=
nction, Co.<BR> <BR> <BR> <BR> Frank-S<BR><BR>
